This can result in pain and discomfort during certain movements or positions, such as the center split you mentioned.

The pain you described in your outer hip with no stretch in your inner thigh is a common symptom of hip impingement. The "stopping pain" you feel is likely due to the compression or irritation of the soft tissues and nerves around the hip joint.

Stretching alone may not be sufficient to address the underlying anatomical issue causing hip impingement. It is important to note that some individuals have anatomical variations that make certain movements or splits challenging or impossible to achieve. In some cases, hip impingement can be addressed with physical therapy exercises, modifications to your sport or activities, and sometimes surgical intervention.

To properly diagnose and determine the best course of action for your specific situation, I would recommend consulting with a healthcare professional who specializes in sports medicine or orthopedics. They will be able to perform a thorough evaluation, which may include imaging studies like X-rays or an MRI, to

The first trimester combined screening test, which includes a blood test and an ultrasound measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT), as well as specific markers in the blood, gave a very low risk for DS of 1:3690. This means that the chance of having a baby with Down syndrome is relatively low.

During the second-trimester anomaly scan, a cystic hygroma (CP cyst) and a mild renal pelvis dilation (RPD) were detected. Given the results of the first trimester screening and the findings on the second-trimester scan, it would be advisable to proceed with further diagnostic testing to obtain a more accurate assessment of the risk. This may include a diagnostic test such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 20 year old female and had sex for the first time. I took Regestrone to delay my periods because I planned to get intimate the same day as my periods. I took them for three to four days before my expected period date and had the tablet two to three times a day. Last dose I had it just the night before having sex. I had sex many times the next night but with protection and took an i-pill to be sure. Next week got light periods that were very painful. But ignored it thinking it was because of hormonal imbalance. Both of us were affected by flu and it turned into a stomach infection with alternate periods of diarrhea and constipation that was accompanied with mild nausea but had no vomiting. I became very weak and then eventually recovered by taking Pantocid, Digene and Zandu pancharishta. I am six days overdue and had slight back pain, nausea and increased urination. I do have migraine issues as well as I am quite obese with a BMI of 33.8. I got two home pregnancy tests done and both of them turned out to be negative. However, I still have not got my periods yet and I have been insisted to check for PCOS and get an ultrasound done. I am worried if the ultrasound shows that I am pregnant. I have gained about 4 kg. Is it possible to get a false negative six weeks after having sex? What can I do to get my periods early? Please advice.

### Response:Based on your description, it is possible that you are experiencing an eye condition called conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye. Conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin, transparent layer of tissue that covers the white part of your eye and lines the inner surface of the eyelids.

The redness, sensitivity to light, pain while moving the eyeballs, and irritation in the center of the eye are common symptoms of conjunctivitis. It can be caused by a bacterial or viral infection, allergies, or irritants such as chemicals or foreign objects.

I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and treatment. They will be able to examine your eye and determine the exact cause of your symptoms. In the meantime, you can try using a warm compress to help alleviate any discomfort.

2. Narcolepsy: This is a neurological disorder characterized by sudden, uncontrollable episodes of excessive daytime sleepiness. Other symptoms may include sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy) and sleep paralysis.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, the black dot that has not gone away since yesterday and does not move when the eye is moved or blinked is concerning for a retinal detachment. Retinal detachment occurs when the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina) pulls away from its normal position. This can cause various symptoms, including seeing floaters or spots, flashing lights, and a sudden onset of dense black curtain-like vision loss.

The fact that the black dot seems to move when the eye is jiggled and slowly descends after shaking the eye further suggests a retinal detachment. Retinal detachments require immediate medical attention, as they can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

It is important for the patient to seek urgent medical attention from an ophthalmologist or go to the nearest emergency department.

raw_output:

### Input:
Hi doctor,Can the adult palate narrow or change shape due to age or stress or hormonal factors?

### Response:Yes, the adult palate can indeed change shape or narrow due to various factors such as age, stress, and hormonal changes. This is known as palatal expansion, and it can occur in both men and women. However, it is more common in women during puberty or pregnancy. The palatal expansion occurs because the maxillary bones, which form the roof of the mouth, have the ability to expand or spread apart. This expansion can lead to a decrease in the width of the hard palate, causing the palate to become narrower. It is important to note that palatal expansion may not always result in a noticeable change in appearance, but it can affect speech and dental alignment. If you have any concerns about palatal expansion or believe that it may be affecting you, I recommend consulting with a dentist or orthodontist for further evaluation and guidance.

input: Hello doctor,I have been getting sores and things that look like blood blisters in my mouth for around six months. I had a swab test and blood work was done to rule out HSV. It came back negative. However, there is still a chance it could be HSV as it takes three to six months to show up in your blood. I am concerned. This is completely out of the normal for me. I do not smoke, drink moderately a few times a week, eat healthily and exercise. Any ideas? Would oral or genital herpes look like this in the mouth? Could it be mouth cancer?

Oral herpes is typically transmitted through close personal contact, such as kissing, and it can take some time for the virus to show up in a blood test.

Oral herpes presents as small, painful blisters or sores on or around the lips, mouth, or throat. These sores may appear in clusters and can sometimes be preceded by symptoms such as tingling, itching, or burning sensations in the affected area. They usually heal on their own within a few days to two weeks, but they can recur from time to time.

Mouth cancer is also a possibility, although it is less likely given your lifestyle choices. However, any persistent or concerning changes in your oral tissues should be evaluated by a healthcare professional, preferably a dentist or a doctor specializing in oral medicine. They will be able to conduct a thorough examination and potentially order further tests, such as a biopsy, if necessary.

In the meantime, avoid sharing utensils, toothbrushes, or other personal items, and practice good oral hygiene to reduce the risk

### Response:Hello! I'm sorry to hear that you're confused about your test results. An echocardiogram and ECG can indeed help in diagnosing restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is a condition where the heart muscle becomes stiff and less compliant, leading to impaired filling of the heart chambers during the diastolic phase. An echocardiogram uses sound waves to create images of the heart, and it can show abnormalities in the size, shape, and movement of the heart walls. It can help identify restrictions in the filling of the heart chambers.

An ECG (electrocardiogram) records the electrical activity of the heart, and it can reveal certain changes associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy, such as altered P-wave patterns or abnormalities in the T-wave.

However, it's important to note that these tests alone may not provide a definitive diagnosis. Other factors, such as the patient's medical history, symptoms, and additional tests, are usually considered in the overall evaluation.

input: Hello doctor,I began presenting last fall with some chronic fatigue. The initial blood work showed low iron saturation without anemia. I have attached reports of the same. There were other endocrine-related findings as well. In the course of various endocrine-related treatments and corresponding blood work, I began iron supplementation in the form of ferrous sulfate 143 mg daily. I began this before the blood work was done. So, you can see that that the levels have increased. Subsequent testing, a month later, showed a decline despite continuing treatment. Most recently, you can see that the levels are back up. Note that the ferritin levels began a bit low around 27 ng/mL and had increased to 30 ng/mL.I have received a wide range of conflicting advice about whether low iron levels in the absence of anemia can cause fatigue. I have also received a range of conflicting advice about whether to continue iron supplementation. One doctor told me to continue taking the iron until the ferritin is up around 50 or so. Another said that would be unnecessary and to discontinue it and wait for three months to re-measure the blood work. It is all quite puzzling. Please help me to understand iron\s role, if any, in fatigue in the absence of anemia. And help me to then understand the rationale for treatment or lack thereof. And finally, please give me some sense of when iron toxicity emerges in terms of blood work measurements and at what frequency one needs to check the iron levels during any supplementation.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems like they are experiencing chronic migraines. Migraine treatment usually involves a combination of acute attacks management and prevention. Here are some recommendations:

1. Acute attacks management:
   - Rest in a quiet, dark room.
   - Apply a cold or warm compress on the head or neck.
   - Take over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or naproxen sodium.
   - Use triptans if prescribed by a doctor.

2. Prevention:
   - Identify triggers and try to avoid them if possible (e.g., certain foods, stress, lack of sleep).
   - Maintain a regular sleep schedule and ensure adequate sleep duration.
   - Practice stress management techniques (e.g., relaxation exercises, meditation).
   - Consider prescription preventive medications such as beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol), antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline), or anticonvulsants (e.g., topiramate).

3. Weight management:
   - Discuss alternative medications for migraine prevention with your healthcare provider that may not cause weight gain.
   - Develop a healthy eating plan and exercise routine

input: Hello doctor,I have just had a sinus lift graft and implants placed. The dentist has prescribed 500 mg of Levofloxacin every 12 hours for 10 days, plus Augmentin, plus Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone. My question is whether the Levofloxacin is necessary and why is it such a high dose? I have read it should not be taken with Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone. My dentist said it is fine, but I am very worried as I have heard this antibiotic is very toxic. What is your advice concerning this issue, please?

My question is whether the Levofloxacin is necessary and why is it such a high dose? I have read it should not be taken with Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone. My dentist said it is fine, but I am very worried as I have heard this antibiotic is very toxic. What is your advice concerning this issue, please?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide some guidance on the prescribed medications for your sinus lift graft and implants. 

Levofloxacin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections. The dose prescribed by your dentist may vary depending on the severity of the infection and individual factors such as your weight and renal function. It is not uncommon to see higher doses of antibiotics being prescribed for certain infections.

While it is true that Levofloxacin should not be taken with Ibuprofen and Dexamethasone, both of which are corticosteroids, your dentist may have specific reasons for prescribing these medications together. Corticosteroids like Dexamethasone can help reduce inflammation and swelling associated with the surgical procedure. Ibuprofen, on the other hand, is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can provide pain relief and reduce inflammation.

It is important to follow your dentist's instructions and take the medications as prescribed. If you have concerns about the safety or interactions of these medications, I would recommend discussing them further with your dentist or healthcare provider. They will be able to provide more information based on your individual situation.

input: Hi doctor, I am taking rabies vaccination. Right now I have completed two doses of my injection. My question is if I get another bite during my vaccination do I have to restart my rabies course from starting or should I continue the same course?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor, I am taking rabies vaccination. Right now I have completed two doses of my injection. My question is if I get another bite during my vaccination do I have to restart my rabies course from starting or should I continue the same course?

### Response:If you receive another bite during your rabies vaccination course, you will not need to restart the vaccination from the beginning. According to the post-exposure prophylaxis guidelines for rabies, if a person receives a bite while undergoing rabies vaccination, an additional dose of vaccine is recommended at the site of the new bite. This additional dose does not require you to start the vaccination course from scratch. You should continue with the same rabies vaccination course as prescribed.

### Response:Based on your description, it is important to seek help for your father. Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings, including manic episodes followed by depressive periods. Abusing alcohol can exacerbate these symptoms.

Here are some steps you can consider taking:

1. Consult with a mental health professional: Encourage your father to see a psychiatrist or psychologist who specializes in bipolar disorder. They can provide an accurate diagnosis and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

2. Educate yourself and others: Learn more about bipolar disorder to increase your understanding of the condition. This will help you empathize with your father and advocate for his needs.

3. Encourage professional treatment: Emphasize the importance of adhering to prescribed medication and attending therapy sessions. Medications such as mood stabilizers can help manage symptoms of bipolar disorder.

4. Create a supportive environment: Offer support and understanding to your father. Encourage him to engage in healthy activities, maintain regular sleep patterns, and avoid alcohol and drugs.

5. Seek family therapy: Involving the entire family in therapy sessions can help improve communication and coping strategies when dealing with bipolar disorder.

4. Which is the best option: daycare or in-la

It would be best for the patient to consult with a sports medicine specialist or orthopedic specialist who can further evaluate the condition and provide appropriate treatment recommendations.

input: Hello doctor,How can I figure out my conception date? My last menstrual period was three months back. I had my dating ultrasound and it put the GA at 9 weeks and 3 days. Also there was a CRL measurement of 26.96. My due date based on LMP and ultrasound are different. Please answer. Also how many "safe" days are there after a period?
raw_output:

### Instruction:

Also there was a CRL measurement of 26.96. My due date based on LMP and ultrasound are different. Please answer. Also how many "safe" days are there after a period?

### Response:To figure out your conception date, you can calculate it by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of your last menstrual period (LMP). So if your LMP started on January 1st, you would add 9 months and 7 days to get a conception date of October 7th.

The gestational age (GA) of 9 weeks and 3 days as per the ultrasound is accurate. This means that your due date based on the ultrasound is also accurate.

The CRL measurement of 26.96 mm is within the normal range for that gestational age.

There are generally considered to be 10-12 "safe" days before and after a period, depending on various factors such as regularity and length of menstrual cycles. These are considered the days when pregnancy is less likely to occur due to the presence of fertile cervical mucus and ovulation. However, it's important to note that pregnancy can still occur outside of these "safe" days, especially if there is unprotected intercourse.

### Response:Based on your description, you are experiencing a phenomenon called breakthrough bleeding or irregular periods. Breakthrough bleeding can occur when you are taking hormonal contraceptives, such as the IUD or birth control pills. It is usually caused by hormonal fluctuations or changes in your body.

In your case, the breakthrough bleeding may be related to the unprotected sex you had on the 30th. The I-pill works by preventing fertilization of the egg or implantation of the fertilized egg in the uterus. However, it will not protect against pregnancy if fertilization has already taken place, which could be the reason for your current bleeding.

It's important to note that while breakthrough bleeding can be concerning, it does not necessarily indicate harmful effects. However, if the bleeding persists or worsens, if you experience severe abdominal pain, fever, or if you have any other concerns, I would recommend seeking medical advice from a healthcare professional. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and provide appropriate guidance.

input: Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Will she be able to have kids?
raw_output:

### Input:
Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it appears that your sister has a karyotype result of 46, XY (20), which means she has an additional X chromosome (XXY) instead of the usual two X chromosomes in females. This condition is known as Klinefelter syndrome.

The small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population mentioned in the report suggest that there may be variations or abnormalities in the chromosomes, although they were not detected using the standard methods employed.

As for treatment options, there is no specific treatment for Klinefelter syndrome. However, your sister may benefit from hormone replacement therapy to address any associated hormonal imbalances and help regulate her menstrual cycle. Fertility options will depend on various factors, including the severity of the condition and the presence of other health issues. It would be best for your sister to consult with a reproductive endocrinologist who can provide more specific information regarding her fertility potential.

It is important for your sister to have regular check-ups with a healthcare provider who specializes in gender-related disorders to monitor her health and address any concerns or questions she may have.

It is important to discuss your ongoing symptoms and concerns with your doctor to determine the most appropriate course of action for you. They will be able to evaluate whether an iron infusion is necessary at this time or if any further investigations or treatments should be considered.

input: Dear Doctor,I am a 29 year old female suffering from PCOD, taking medicines from past 1 year. But still it has not reduced. I was into Metformin and Folic acid. At the same time I have also taken medicines for conception (i.e, clomiphene).Follicar study has been conducted for four times and only once the egg ruptured, but I did not conceive.From december onwards the follicles are not maturing upto required level.Again during February and March my doctor put me on K-35 as my periods during past 1 year were not regular and still are irregular (I have to take tablet Norgest thrice daily for 5 days and then periods come).Recently I have consulted another doctor, she has prescribed me to stop taking Metformin and instead to start on APCOD sachet (Myo-inositol) and Safegest D (dehydroepiandrosterone) and during periods Adova (Anastrozole).But I have not yet started the medicines. I am a bit confused, whether should I totally stop Metformin and start with these new drugs?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:

### Input:
Dear Doctor,I am a 29 year old female suffering from PCOD, taking medicines from past 1 year. But still it has not reduced. I was into Metformin and Folic acid. At the same time I have also taken medicines for conception (i.e, clomiphene).Follicar study has been conducted for four times and only once the egg ruptured, but I did not conceive.From december onwards the follicles are not maturing upto required level.Again during February and March my doctor put me on K-35 as my periods during past 1 year were not regular and still are irregular (I have to take tablet Norgest thrice daily for 5 days and then periods come).Recently I have consulted another doctor, she has prescribed me to stop taking Metformin and instead to start on APCOD sachet (Myo-inositol) and Safegest D (dehydroepiandrosterone) and during periods Adova (Anastrozole).But I have not yet started the medicines. I am a bit confused, whether should I totally stop Metformin and start with these new drugs?

### Response:As an AI, I am not a doctor and cannot provide medical advice. However, I can give you some general information.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a hormonal disorder that affects women of reproductive age. It can lead to irregular periods, infertility, and other symptoms. Treatment for PCOS often involves lifestyle changes, such as regular exercise and a healthy diet, as well as medications to regulate hormones and help with symptoms.

Metformin is commonly used to treat insulin resistance, which is often associated with PCOS. It helps improve insulin sensitivity and can help regulate menstrual cycles. Folic acid is important for reproductive health and may be prescribed to support conception.

Clomiphene is a medication commonly used to stimulate ovulation in women trying to conceive. It works by blocking estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus and pituitary gland, which increases the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone, thus stimulating the ovaries.

Follicar studies involve monitoring follicular development using ultrasound scans during the menstrual cycle. This can help determine the best time to administer assisted reproductive technologies

input: Hello doctor,My daughter is 6 years old. About 10 to 11 months back we saw a very very small dark black colored dot on her side of the tongue. But now there are 4 to 5 similar sized dot around her tongue on both sides. The size has not grown. But it is just that new location has emerged. Lately she is continuously touching her tongue and her tip of tongue appears red. She says she feels like there is a hair on her tongue and there is some sensation on her tongue. I do not know if she is able to correctly describe her feeling. I am more worried about the black spots. Rest she is absolutely fine. Please advice.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My daughter is 6 years old. About 10 to 11 months back we saw a very very small dark black colored dot on her side of the tongue. But now there are 4 to 5 similar sized dot around her tongue on both sides. The size has not grown. But it is just that new location has emerged. Lately she is continuously touching her tongue and her tip of tongue appears red. She says she feels like there is a hair on her tongue and there is some sensation on her tongue. I do not know if she is able to correctly describe her feeling. I am more worried about the black spots. Rest she is absolutely fine. Please advice.

### Response:Based on your description, it is possible that your daughter is experiencing a condition called lingual papillomatosis. This condition is characterized by the appearance of small, dark spots on the tongue, which can later spread to other areas. The spots are usually painless and not considered cancerous.

The redness and irritation of the tip of the tongue may be due to chronic rubbing or scratching of the spots, which can cause inflammation. It is important to note that this condition is usually benign and self-limiting, meaning it will likely resolve on its own without treatment.

To alleviate your concerns and ensure your daughter's overall health, I recommend taking her to a pediatrician or a pediatric dentist for further evaluation. They will be able to examine her tongue and provide appropriate guidance based on her specific symptoms and medical history.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 34 year old male. I had anxiety issues since childhood. I have been jumping from one idea to another for a long time but it has been three years I have an issue with frequent urination. It started in a bad time for me when I was obsessing that I have HIV. No burning, just slight urethra burning. I went to a urologist. He told me nothing was wrong, maybe an overactive bladder. I go to the toilet every two hours or three. I never knew what was wrong, but I started to obsess over it and it got worse to a place that my mind is in urination 24/7. I almost gave up until I went on a vacation and during that vacation, I forgot about it totally. The frequency was gone and even the burning urethra. Also, I had to remove my wisdom teeth and when I did, I was so occupied thinking about it that I forgot about urination and I noticed that I do not use the bathroom like I used to. But, I got back obsessing about it again and it got to a point that I urinate a lot of high volumes every hour. It comes suddenly and goes on its own. I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. Can anxiety cause polyuria like this clear urine when I am stressed?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

I almost gave up until I went on a vacation and during that vacation, I forgot about it totally. The frequency was gone and even the burning urethra. Also, I had to remove my wisdom teeth and when I did, I was so occupied thinking about it that I forgot about urination and I noticed that I do not use the bathroom like I used to. But, I got back obsessing about it again and it got to a point that I urinate a lot of high volumes every hour. It comes suddenly and goes on its own. I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. Can anxiety cause polyuria like this clear urine when I am stressed?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that anxiety can cause polyuria (frequent urination) and clear urine when stressed. Anxiety can affect the function of the bladder and urinary system, leading to increased urine production and more frequent urination.

However, it is important to note that frequent urination can also be caused by other medical conditions or factors such as urinary tract infections, bladder stones, bladder or prostate enlargement, diabetes, or certain medications. Therefore, it would be advisable for the patient to consult with a healthcare professional, preferably a urologist, for a thorough evaluation and proper diagnosis.

The urologist may conduct further tests such as urinalysis, urine culture, blood work, imaging studies, or cystoscopy to determine the underlying cause of the symptoms and provide appropriate treatment options. It is essential to address the issue to alleviate the patient's concerns and improve their quality of life.

### Response:Based on the description and pictures you provided, it appears that you are experiencing a condition known as "retinoid dermatitis." This is a common side effect of using retinoid medications, such as Retin-A ointment.

Retinoid dermatitis typically presents as redness, peeling, and dryness in the areas where the medication has been applied. It is important to note that this reaction is usually mild and temporary, and should improve once you stop using the medication.

To help alleviate the symptoms and promote healing, it is recommended to use moisturizers and emollients, such as Cerave ointment, regularly. Additionally, avoiding direct sunlight exposure and using gentle cleansers can also be beneficial.

If your symptoms persist or worsen, I would advise consulting with a dermatologist for further evaluation and guidance. They may suggest alternative treatment options or provide specific instructions tailored to your individual needs.

input: Hi doctor,I am in a little trouble. Summer has started where I live, and I am addicted to playing cricket, whatever the weather or climate be. From last two weeks, I have noticed that my face color has become darker due to the sun. So, I am a little confused about which sunblock cream to use. I need your suggestion on which cream to use. I do not understand the concept of SPF 25, 30, 50 and 60.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am in a little trouble. Summer has started where I live, and I am addicted to playing cricket, whatever the weather or climate be. From last two weeks, I have noticed that my face color has become darker due to the sun. So, I am a little confused about which sunblock cream to use. I need your suggestion on which cream to use. I do not understand the concept of SPF 25, 30, 50 and 60.

### Response:As a doctor, I can help you with your concerns about sun protection. The SPF (sun protection factor) measures the effectiveness of a sunscreen in blocking UVB rays, which are responsible for sunburns. A higher SPF indicates better protection against UVB rays.

Here's how the different SPF values relate to each other:
- SPF 25 filters out about 96% of UVB rays
- SPF 50 filters out around 98%
- SPF 60 filters out approximately 98%

So, generally speaking, the higher the SPF, the better. However, it's important to note that no sunscreen can block 100% of UVB rays, and it's always advisable to seek shade and wear protective clothing in addition to using sunscreen.

When choosing a sunblock cream, look for one that is broad-spectrum, meaning it protects against both UVA and UVB rays. It should also be water-resistant if you plan to be sweating or swimming.

Finally, remember to apply sunscreen generously and reapply every two hours, especially if you are outdoors and exposed to the sun.

I hope this helps!

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?

### Response:The regular contraceptive pill and the emergency contraceptive pill have different functions and are used under different circumstances.

The regular contraceptive pill, also known as the combined oral contraceptive (COC) pill, is taken daily by women who wish to prevent pregnancy. It contains synthetic hormones that work to inhibit ovulation, thicken cervical mucus, and thin the uterine lining, making it less receptive to fertilization.

On the other hand, the emergency contraceptive pill, such as the I-pill, is taken after unprotected sex or following contraceptive failure to prevent pregnancy. It is typically used within 72-120 hours (3-5 days) after unprotected intercourse but is more effective if taken sooner. The emergency contraceptive pill acts primarily by delaying or inhibiting ovulation, but it may also affect fertilization or implantation of a fertilized egg.

To summarize:
- Regular contraceptive pill: taken daily to prevent pregnancy
- Emergency contraceptive pill: taken after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy after a contraceptive failure.

I hope this clarifies the difference between these two types of pills. Please consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice regarding emergency contraception.

input: Hello doctor,55 years old male with complaint of ptosis on the right eye having diabetes for the past 10 to 12 years. FBS yesterday taken was 165 mg/dl. ### Input:
Hello doctor,55 years old male with complaint of ptosis on the right eye having diabetes for the past 10 to 12 years. FBS yesterday taken was 165 mg/dl. Ocular movement normal on left side but adduction limited in affected side. He is suspected to have third nerve palsy. What all medical intervention can be possible to get normal?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, there are several possible medical interventions for the treatment of third nerve palsy leading to ptosis in the right eye. These may include:

1. Diabetic management: It is important to optimize blood sugar control to prevent further complications and improve the overall health of the patient. This may involve lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and medication adjustments.

2. Ophthalmologic evaluation: The patient should be referred to an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive eye examination. They may recommend specific treatments or interventions specific to the underlying cause of the third nerve palsy.

3. Orbital massage and exercises: Gentle massage and exercises of the orbital muscles surrounding the eye can help improve adduction limited in the affected side. This can be performed by an occupational therapist or under their guidance.

4. Eye drops or oral medications: Depending on the underlying cause, the doctor may prescribe certain eye drops or oral medications to help alleviate symptoms and improve muscle function.

5. Surgical intervention: In some cases, surgical procedures such as a frontalis sling or levator resection may be necessary to correct the ptosis and improve eyelid movement.

6

input: Hi doctor,I am having my Mirena IUD removed today. I have had regular cycles the entire five years of having it. How soon can I conceive?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am having my Mirena IUD removed today. I have had regular cycles the entire five years of having it. How soon can I conceive?

### Response:The Mirena IUD is a hormonal intrauterine device that releases small amounts of progestin to prevent pregnancy. It can alter the user's menstrual cycle, causing it to become more regular and predictable. 

When you have your Mirena IUD removed, your menstrual cycle should return to its natural pattern rather quickly. The average duration of fertility after discontinuing use of hormonal contraceptives like the Mirena IUD is approximately 6-12 months. However, this varies from person to person and can depend on various factors such as age, overall health, and previous reproductive history.

It's important to note that after having your Mirena IUD removed, it is recommended to use another form of contraception, such as condoms or another method of birth control, if you do not wish to conceive immediately. This will provide a greater degree of contraceptive certainty until your natural fertility returns.

Please consult with your healthcare provider for personalized advice regarding your specific situation.

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.

input: Hello doctor,I have a lot of black spots on my face and upper back due to the popping of pimples. To where it is darkening my skin making me uncomfortable with myself. I have been clueless about the medication I should use that would help my situation.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have a lot of black spots on my face and upper back due to the popping of pimples. To where it is darkening my skin making me uncomfortable with myself. I have been clueless about the medication I should use that would help my situation.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) due to the popping of pimples. PIH can occur when there is an injury or inflammation to the skin, leading to an increased production of melanin in that area.

To help with PIH, there are several options you can try:

1. Topical creams: Over-the-counter creams containing ingredients like hydroquinone, kojic acid, retinoids, and azelaic acid can help reduce the appearance of hyperpigmentation. These creams work by reducing melanin production and promoting cell turnover.

2. Chemical peels: A chemical peel can be performed by a dermatologist to exfoliate the skin and improve the appearance of hyperpigmentation. Different types of chemicals are used during the peel to remove the outer layers of the skin and stimulate new collagen production.

3. Laser or light therapy: Certain lasers and light-based treatments, such as intense pulsed light (IPL) or q-switched lasers, can effectively treat PIH by targeting the excess pigment in the skin. These treatments work by either breaking up the pigment or reducing its production.

4

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing a condition called "Dermatitis herpetiformis." Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, fluid-filled blisters or bumps on the skin. It is not contagious and does not appear to be hereditary.

Dermatitis herpetiformis typically occurs in individuals with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease. The condition is caused by an immune reaction to gluten, which leads to the formation of bumps and itching. However, not everyone with dermatitis herpetiformis has digestive symptoms or is diagnosed with celiac disease.

The annual flare-up you described, starting in December and ending in February or March, is consistent with the seasonal pattern often seen in dermatitis herpetiformis. Cold weather may trigger the condition or exacerbate symptoms.

It is important to note that while this condition is not life-threatening, it can significantly impact your quality of life. If over-the-counter treatments are not effective in managing the symptoms, I would recommend seeking the advice of a dermatologist. They can provide appropriate prescription medications and further guidance for managing this condition.

2. Amount of blood: Small amounts of blood in the phlegm may not necessarily require medical attention, but if the blood is present in large amounts or appears as clots, it could be more concerning.

3. Other symptoms: Any accompanying symptoms such as chest pain, difficulty breathing, high fever, weight loss, or generalized weakness may indicate a more severe condition and would likely require medical evaluation.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 31 year old female. Height is 5\3" and weight 71 kg. I have normal skin. I have started developing fine lines on my face. Just recently I have developed a slight depression in the form of a line starting from under the inner side of the eye running down the cheek (photo attached). I think this is the beginning of cheek sagging. Is this premature aging? Can this be reverted with non-invasive techniques like topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages or exercises?Someone suggested me to use Retinol-A, which I have started using and is suiting me well. I have read a lot about the benefits of topical retinoid, vitamin E and C serum. Please suggest the best ones as I have heard that most of the available vitamin C serums in the market are useless as they oxidize easily and do not penetrate the skin. I have seen some videos of facial exercises online. Do you think they are effective? Also let me know how often should I get facials and which one is for anti-aging? I am also trying to put down weight. In this process I will naturally lose some fat from my face as well, but I do not want my facial skin to become loose. What should I do for this?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am a 31 year old female. Height is 5\3" and weight 71 kg. I have normal skin. I have started developing fine lines on my face. Just recently I have developed a slight depression in the form of a line starting from under the inner side of the eye running down the cheek (photo attached). I think this is the beginning of cheek sagging. Is this premature aging? Can this be reverted with non-invasive techniques like topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages or exercises?Someone suggested me to use Retinol-A, which I have started using and is suiting me well. I have read a lot about the benefits of topical retinoid, vitamin E and C serum. Please suggest the best ones as I have heard that most of the available vitamin C serums in the market are useless as they oxidize easily and do not penetrate the skin. I have seen some videos of facial exercises online. Do you think they are effective? Also let me know how often should I get facials and which one is for anti-aging? I am also trying to put down weight. In this process I will naturally lose some fat from my face as well, but I do not want my facial skin to become loose. What should I do for this?

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing some signs of facial aging. The fine lines on your face and the development of a slight depression running down your cheek are indicative of cheek sagging or nasolabial folds.

While topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages, and exercises can help improve the appearance of your skin and provide some temporary benefits, they may not be sufficient to reverse premature aging. Invasive techniques such as dermal fillers or surgical procedures like a facelift may be more effective in addressing the deeper folds and sagging.

Retinol-A is a commonly used topical retinoid that can help improve skin texture and reduce the appearance of fine lines. Vitamin C serums can also be beneficial for brightening and firming the skin. However, it is important to choose high-quality products that contain stable forms of vitamin C to ensure optimal efficacy.

Facial exercises may help tone the muscles of the face, but they are unlikely to address the underlying sagging or creases. It is essential to consult with a dermatologist or aesthetic specialist who can evaluate your specific concerns and recommend appropriate treatment options tailored to your needs.

In terms of weight loss, maintaining a healthy weight is important for overall skin health

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am 47 today. I went to my primary doctor three years ago with low libido and poor quality erections. Blood work came back as total testosterone 381 and A1c 6.9. Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you have been experiencing low libido and poor quality erections for the past three years. During this time, your total testosterone levels have fluctuated from 381 to 900 ng/dL, while your A1c levels have decreased from 6.9 to 6.0.

It is important to note that the normal range for total testosterone levels can vary depending on the laboratory reference range used. However, in general, a total testosterone level below 300 ng/dL is considered low for adult males.

Regarding your symptoms persisting despite an increase in testosterone levels, this suggests the possibility of testosterone resistance. Testosterone resistance occurs when the body's tissues are unable to respond normally to the presence of testosterone. This can result in decreased sensitivity to the effects of testosterone, leading to symptoms such as low libido and poor erectile quality.

The recommendation of testosterone replacement therapy (TRT) along with Clomid by your primary care doctor seems reasonable. TRT involves the administration of exogenous testosterone to supplement the deficient levels in the body. Clomid, on the other hand, is a medication that stimulates the production of natural testosterone in the body.

input: Hi doctor,One year back, while sitting on a chair in office I felt as if my back got stuck and was unable to move. I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. I am only 27 years old and unable to do simple tasks like sitting for five minutes. Please help me, what could be the possible reason for all this.I had some back pain three years ago. My lifestyle is also not good. I do not used to any exercise or walk earlier, only sitting on a chair in front of a computer for 10-11 hours. I have also gained weight of 15 kg in 10 months. Right now, I am taking only Vitamin D3 supplement. I am attaching all my reports for your reference.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems that you have a chronic condition of constipation that has persisted for a long time. While I cannot provide a diagnosis without conducting a physical examination and obtaining more information about your medical history, there are several potential causes of chronic constipation. These may include:

1. Hypothyroidism: An underactive thyroid gland can slow down bowel movements.
2. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS): This condition can cause abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits, including constipation.
3. Intestinal obstruction or blockage: This can impede the normal passage of stool through the intestines.
4. Neurological disorders: Conditions such as multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injuries can affect nerve signals that regulate bowel movements.
5. Medications: Certain medications, such as antacids, antidepressants, opioid pain relievers, and iron supplements, can contribute to constipation.

It is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your symptoms, perform a physical examination, and order any necessary tests to determine the underlying cause of your chronic constipation. They will be able to provide appropriate treatment recommendations based on their findings.

### Response:Based on your description, it is difficult to determine with certainty what exactly broke off from your tooth. However, based on the location and appearance you described, it is likely that you are referring to either tartar or cementum.

Tartar, also known as calculus, is a hardened form of plaque that forms on the tooth surface. It is composed of minerals and bacteria and can only be removed through professional dental cleaning. Cementum, on the other hand, is a layer of smooth tissue that covers the root of the tooth and is part of the tooth structure.

If the broken material is indeed tartar or cementum, it is not typically harmful to leave it alone. Tartar and cementum are both natural components of the tooth structure and do not typically cause any symptoms or discomfort.

However, if you are concerned about the appearance or feel of the broken material, you can consider visiting a dentist for a professional evaluation. The dentist will be able to examine your teeth and provide appropriate advice based on their findings.

In summary, if the broken material is tartar or cementum, and it is not causing any symptoms, there may be no need for immediate action. However, consulting with a dentist would be recommended for a thorough evaluation and guidance.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide some information regarding your concerns. It is important to note that I cannot establish a diagnosis or provide specific medical advice without directly assessing you. However, I can give you some general information.

1. Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB): LBBB is a condition characterized by an abnormality in the electrical conduction system of the heart, specifically involving the left bundle branch. It can be caused by various factors, including age, underlying heart diseases, or certain medications. LBBB itself does not usually cause symptoms but may be associated with other heart problems.

2. Stress Echocardiograms: Stress echocardiograms are commonly used to assess heart function during physical exertion. They use ultrasound waves to create images of the heart and evaluate its pumping ability. Stress echocardiography can be performed using either exercise or pharmacological stress agents. In patients with LBBB, stress echocardiography can help determine if there is significant impairment of cardiac function during stress.

3. Nuclear Stress Echocardiogram: A nuclear stress echocardiogram involves injecting a small amount of radioactive material into the bloodstream before performing a stress echocardiogram. This allows for specialized imaging of the heart's blood flow and function.

input: Hi doctor,I had a c-section with my first pregnancy 19 years ago. I have fallen in love with a wonderful man who does not have kids. I and my fiance have been discussing and are planning to have a baby. I am concerned if I am able to have a VBAC delivery with my second pregnancy since my first pregnancy resulted in an emergency C-section. Also, I am 48. What are the risks of pregnancy in women over 40?
raw_output:

I and my fiance have been discussing and are planning to have a baby. I am concerned if I am able to have a VBAC delivery with my second pregnancy since my first pregnancy resulted in an emergency C-section. Also, I am 48. What are the risks of pregnancy in women over 40?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with some information regarding your concerns. 

1. VBAC delivery: The ability to have a vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) delivery depends on various factors such as the type of incision made during your previous C-section, the duration since your previous C-section, and your overall health. It is important to discuss this with your healthcare provider, who can evaluate your specific case and advise you on the potential risks and benefits of attempting a VBAC delivery.

2. Pregnancy risks in women over 40: As a woman gets older, the risks associated with pregnancy generally increase. Some potential risks include an increased chance of genetic abnormalities in the fetus, higher likelihood of developing gestational diabetes or high blood pressure during pregnancy, and a small increase in the risk of preterm birth or low birth weight. However, it's important to note that many women successfully carry and deliver healthy babies at age 40 and beyond.

It is crucial to consult with your healthcare provider before attempting a pregnancy, especially considering your age and previous C-section. They will be able to provide you with personalized guidance based on your medical history and help you make informed decisions regarding your fertility and pregnancy options.

Hypoestrogenism occurs when there is a decrease in the hormone estrogen, which is responsible for maintaining the integrity and elasticity of the breast tissue.

2. Thyroid disorders: Certain thyroid conditions, such as hypothyroidism, can lead to decreased hormone production.
3. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a hormonal disorder that can cause irregular menstrual periods and fluctuations in hormone levels.

5. Medications: Certain medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or hormonal contraceptives, may affect estrogen levels.

input: Hello doctor,I am undergoing Q-switched laser treatment along with the use of Hydroquinone to treat my melasma. However, I would like to know if the use of stem cell creams can worsen the melasma by encouraging the growth of melanin? Currently, I am taking Tranexamic acid, Cipramil, Valdoxan.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am undergoing Q-switched laser treatment along with the use of Hydroquinone to treat my melasma. However, I would like to know if the use of stem cell creams can worsen the melasma by encouraging the growth of melanin? Currently, I am taking Tranexamic acid, Cipramil, Valdoxan.

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide some information regarding your concern. Melasma is a skin condition characterized by the darkening of certain areas of the face. It is believed to be caused by an increased production of melanin, the pigment responsible for skin color.

Stem cell creams contain components that are designed to stimulate the regeneration of stem cells in the skin. While the exact mechanism of action varies depending on the specific ingredients in the cream, they typically aim to promote collagen production and improve overall skin health.

However, stem cell creams do not directly encourage the growth of melanin. Melanin production is primarily controlled by genetic and hormonal factors. In most cases, melasma does not respond to topical treatments alone and requires a combination therapy approach, which may include medications like hydroquinone, sun protection, and sometimes oral medications like tranexamic acid, cipramil, or valdoxan.

It is important to consult with your dermatologist or healthcare provider regarding the use of stem cell creams in conjunction with your current treatment plan. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and provide personalized recommendations based on your medical history and the severity of your melasma.

input: Hello doctor,I am 30 years old male with HTN (Telmisartan 49 mg and CTD 6.25 mg) for past six years with a body weight of 80 kg. For some days I have noticed froth in urine and facial puffiness. I want your suggestion. My RFT was normal but I have not checked my urine for protein or USG abdomen. Can you please guide me regarding further management?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am 30 years old male with HTN (Telmisartan 49 mg and CTD 6.25 mg) for past six years with a body weight of 80 kg. For some days I have noticed froth in urine and facial puffiness. I want your suggestion. My RFT was normal but I have not checked my urine for protein or USG abdomen. Can you please guide me regarding further management?

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you may have a kidney problem called nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by the presence of excess protein in the urine, leading to frothiness or foam. Facial puffiness can also occur due to fluid retention.

To further evaluate your condition, I would recommend the following:

1. Check for protein in the urine: You can do this by collecting a urine sample and sending it to the laboratory for a test called protein-to-creatinine ratio or urinary protein electrophoresis.

2. Abdominal ultrasound: This imaging test can help assess the kidneys for any structural abnormalities or signs of inflammation.

3. Blood tests: Measurements of blood pressure, cholesterol, and kidney function including serum creatinine and estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) should be obtained.

Once these investigations are complete, you should consult with a nephrologist or a kidney specialist who will review the results and provide appropriate management based on your specific condition.

Please note that this response is based on the information provided, and it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and personalized treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,Diagnosed with varicocele grade 2. I have a lot of queries. Can it be treated? Will varicocele affect my sexual life? Will it lead to infertility (what are the percentages of chances) or is it controversial? Will sexual activity complicate my varicocele? Should I avoid sexual intercourse? Can I go to the gym?
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:

Will it lead to infertility (what are the percentages of chances) or is it controversial? Will sexual activity complicate my varicocele? Should I avoid sexual intercourse? Can I go to the gym?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with information regarding varicocele. 

Varicocele is a condition characterized by enlarged veins in the scrotum. It is usually treated if it causes symptoms or complications. Treatment options for varicocele include surgical repair or embolization. The choice of treatment depends on factors such as the severity of symptoms, desire for future fertility, and presence of other conditions.

Varicocele can potentially affect sexual function and fertility. In some cases, it may lead to testicular atrophy or decreased testosterone levels, which can impact sexual desire and performance. However, the impact on fertility can vary. Studies suggest that the chance of fertility impairment increases with the severity of varicocele. The overall percentage of men with varicocele who experience infertility ranges from about 10% to 25%.

Physical activity, including sexual activity, does not typically complicate varicocele or worsen the condition. However, activities that involve heavy lifting or intense physical exertion should be avoided until after surgical repair, if necessary.

It is always best to consult with your healthcare provider for personalized advice regarding varicocele management and treatment options. They will consider your specific situation and guide you accordingly.

### Response:Hepatitis B is not typically transmitted through saliva. It is primarily transmitted through contact with infected blood or other body fluids such as semen or vaginal fluids.

Antiviral medications can help suppress viral replication and reduce liver inflammation. In some cases, a combination of medications and lifestyle changes can lead to long-term remission. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional who specializes in viral hepatitis to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for your specific situation.

The timeframe for a potential cure cannot be determined without further evaluation by a medical professional. Regular monitoring of liver function and viral load is necessary to assess response to treatment and disease progression.

input: Hello doctor,I am writing for my daughter, staying away from us, with her husband. She is 30 years, 5 feet 1 inch and 63 kg, working in the IT sector. She is married for the last three years and seriously trying for conception from a year. She missed her period once in the beginning of this year. During her obstetrics consultation, beta hCG was done. It was repeated after two days. A transvaginal ultrasound scan was done and repeated after 10 days. The end result was diagnosed as a blighted ovum. So, it was evacuated by D and C.Our daughter is of normal build and nutrition. Her menstrual history was normal since the beginning in terms of cycle, duration, and flow. But, one month after D and C, she did not have her period. On the doctor's advice, she took some medicines and bleeding occurred. She was known hypothyroid. So, she was taking Thyroxin 50 or 75 to keep the TSH near about 2.5 Uiu/ml. Her Hb % and sugar are within the normal range.Again, she tried to conceive since three months ago along with Aspirin and folic acid. She missed her period last month. Her beta hCG was 9.20 mIu/ mL. It was repeated after two days. It came down to 1 Miu/ml suggestive of \chemical pregnancy\. This time, after a few days, a spontaneous jelly-like bleeding occurred for two days. I would like to add that her husband requires to take Penegra 50 mg tab before a performance. Our daughter is immunized with triple antigen, polio, MMR, chickenpox and hepatitis B vaccine in childhood. The transvaginal scan (done at a later phase of the first conception) showed normal anatomical and physiological pattern of the ovary and uterus to me at least (report attached).Two consecutive miscarriages brought great disappointment to all. Presently, the doctor told her to take Aspirin 150 mg, folic acid, and Vitamin B12 combination tablet and to try for pregnancy again. The primary benefit of a ketone diet is its ability to induce ketosis, which is a metabolic state where the body primarily burns fat for fuel instead of carbohydrates.

When in ketosis, the body produces ketones (by breaking down fat) that can provide an alternative energy source for the brain and other organs. This can have several potential benefits, including improved brain function, increased weight loss, better insulin sensitivity, and reduced inflammation.

input: Hi doctor,My 4 years son had a cough for two days. Now his cough is fine but now he has a high fever on the head side but his hands are ice cold. He is telling pain sometimes in hands and some times in feet. What is the cause? Please explain.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My 4 years son had a cough for two days. Now his cough is fine but now he has a high fever on the head side but his hands are ice cold. He is telling pain sometimes in hands and some times in feet. What is the cause? Please explain.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you have described, it is possible that your son may be experiencing Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is an illness that primarily affects children and causes inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body.

The high fever on the head side but ice-cold hands are characteristic symptoms of Kawasaki disease. Other common symptoms include a persistent cough, red eyes without tears, swollen lymph nodes (especially in the neck), rash, and irritability or changes in behavior. In some cases, children with Kawasaki disease may also experience pain or irritation in their hands and feet.

It is important to consult a doctor immediately if you suspect your child may have Kawasaki disease, as prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications. The doctor will conduct a physical examination and may order additional tests such as echocardiogram and blood tests to confirm the diagnosis.

Please seek medical attention as soon as possible to determine the cause of your son's symptoms and receive appropriate treatment.

input: Hi doctor, I have been taking Effexor XR 300 mg for depression. It has been working really well. My psychiatrist has now prescribed me Strattera for ADHD. I am about to start 25 mg and work my way upto 80 mg over a few weeks. Strattera and Effexor both seem to inhibit Norepinephrine reuptake. Is it safe to take this combination? I know my psychiatrist knows what he is doing, but I wanted to get a second opinion from others.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

Hi doctor, I have been taking Effexor XR 300 mg for depression. It has been working really well. My psychiatrist has now prescribed me Strattera for ADHD. I am about to start 25 mg and work my way upto 80 mg over a few weeks. Strattera and Effexor both seem to inhibit Norepinephrine reuptake. Is it safe to take this combination? I know my psychiatrist knows what he is doing, but I wanted to get a second opinion from others.

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide you with some information regarding the combination of Effexor XR and Strattera for treating depression and ADHD.

Both Effexor XR and Strattera work by affecting the levels of neurotransmitters in the brain. Effexor XR inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, while Strattera affects the reuptake of norepinephrine.

Taking these medications together may increase the risk of side effects, such as increased heart rate, high blood pressure, and anxiety. It is important to monitor your blood pressure and heart rate regularly if you decide to take this combination.

It is always recommended to consult with your psychiatrist before making any changes to your medication regimen. They will be able to assess your specific situation and provide personalized advice based on your medical history and current symptoms.

Please discuss any concerns or questions you have with your psychiatrist to ensure the safety and effectiveness of this combination.
